Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Substrate Activation and Catalysis by Low-Coordinate Metal Isocyanides
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program supports work by Professor Joshua S. Figueroa at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) to carry out fundamental studies on transition metal complexes in unique geometric and electronic structure environments. The specific goal of this work centers on the construction of transition metal isocyanide complexes with low coordination numbers. Such complexes have long been identified theoretically and in the gas phase, but are unknown in the condensed phase. However, these molecules promise to elicit a multitude of new reactivity patterns that are not only of fundamental interest, but will have significance in alternative energy processes, catalysis and commodity chemical production. Accordingly, the project sets forth general strategies for the synthesis of low-coordinate transition metal isocyanide complexes and details ensuing reactivity studies.

The main focus of the education component of this project is to increase participation of a culturally diverse range of undergraduate and high school students in modern chemical research. Specifically, undergraduate and advanced high school students are introduced to modern computational chemistry methods through a formal introductory seminar course. Quantum chemical calculations are performed remotely by the students at the NSF funded San Diego Supercomputer Center located on the UCSD campus. Students then interface with faculty from UCSD and other Southern California institutions to use computational techniques to solve cutting-edge chemical research problems. This program is intended to serve as a distributed computational resource for practicing research chemists throughout the Southern California Region.

This project uncovers new and important properties for transition metal containing molecules and positively impacts a broad range of problems including alternative energy conversion, carbon dioxide remediation and waste reduction in commodity chemical production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award CHE-0954710 focused on the synthesis of low-coordinate transition-metal isocyanide complexes as structural, electronic and functional mimics of the unstable unsaturated binary metal carbonyls. Exploiting the isolobal analogy between carbon monoxide (CO) and isocyanides (CNR), and the encumbering steric properties of the m-terphenyl group, this project aimed to generate isolable model complexes of matrix-isolated, low-coordinate metal carbonyls and/or catalytic intermediates in process mediated by metal carbonyls. In addition, synthetic studies were conducted for the use of low-coordinate isocyanide complexes for the discovery of new small-molecule activation processes and mechanistic paradigms in organometallic chemistry. The award period resulted in 15 publications, with additional work in preparation. The key results from the award period include:

1) The synthesis of electronically unsaturated tetraisocyanide complexes of cobalt.

2) The synthesis of  Isocyanide Analogues of Co2(CO)8, HCo(CO)4 and RCo(CO)3, which are all intermediates in Co-catalyzed hydroformylation.

3) Synthetic Studies Targeting Coordinatively Unsaturated Group 6 Isocyanides.

4) Small-Molecule Activation and Mechanistic Studies using Group 10 Isocyanide Complexes.

 In addition, NSF Award CHE-0954710 lead to significant efforts aimed at increasing participation of undergraduate students, especially under-represented persons (URPs), in chemical research. Between 2010 and 2014, 21 undergraduate students worked on this project, with 8 different individuals listed as authors on publications (3 are first-authors). Several of these students have since enrolled in highly-ranked graduate programs. In 2013, the PI also started a new effort of providing research opportunities to transferees from Southern California area junior colleges, many of whom are URPs. In addition, the PI established a successful program of chemistry-enrichment experiences for local high school and youth-group students, again with an emphasis on URPs.  Lastly, the PI completed curricular innovations in inorganic chemistry These efforts formed the basis for the ROA-supplement CHE-1440501 to potentially apply these innovations to a widely used undergaduate textbook in inorganic chemistry. 


Last Modified: 04/08/2015
Modified by: Joshua S Figueroa
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: NSF Award CHE-0954710 focused on the synthesis of low-coordinate transition-metal isocyanide complexes as structural, electronic and functional mimics of the unstable unsaturated binary metal carbonyls. Exploiting the isolobal analogy between carbon monoxide (CO) and isocyanides (CNR), and the encumbering steric properties of the m-terphenyl group, this project aimed to generate isolable model complexes of matrix-isolated, low-coordinate metal carbonyls and/or catalytic intermediates in process mediated by metal carbonyls. In addition, synthetic studies were conducted for the use of low-coordinate isocyanide complexes for the discovery of new small-molecule activation processes and mechanistic paradigms in organometallic chemistry. The award period resulted in 15 publications, with additional work in preparation. The key results from the award period include: 1) The synthesis of electronically unsaturated tetraisocyanide complexes of cobalt. 2) The synthesis of Isocyanide Analogues of Co2(CO)8, HCo(CO)4 and RCo(CO)3, which are all intermediates in Co-catalyzed hydroformylation. 3) Synthetic Studies Targeting Coordinatively Unsaturated Group 6 Isocyanides. 4) Small-Molecule Activation and Mechanistic Studies using Group 10 Isocyanide Complexes. In addition, NSF Award CHE-0954710 lead to significant efforts aimed at increasing participation of undergraduate students, especially under-represented persons (URPs), in chemical research. Between 2010 and 2014, 21 undergraduate students worked on this project, with 8 different individuals listed as authors on publications (3 are first-authors). Several of these students have since enrolled in highly-ranked graduate programs. In 2013, the PI also started a new effort of providing research opportunities to transferees from Southern California area junior colleges, many of whom are URPs. In addition, the PI established a successful program of chemistry-enrichment experiences for local high school and youth-group students, again with an emphasis on URPs. Lastly, the PI completed curricular innovations in inorganic chemistry These efforts formed the basis for the ROA-supplement CHE-1440501 to potentially apply these innovations to a widely used undergaduate textbook in inorganic chemistry.
